awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Pricing and Matching with Asymmetric Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research on two projects in economic theory. The first examines how a monopolist will choose prices over time, with a focus on how monopoly power in the product market affects how the firm makes decisions over time about production technologies. The second project is in the general area of mechanism design, the design of methods to allocate recourses. The specific application is in matching markets under incomplete information, and the work could give us new ideas about how to design allocation methods that will lead to stable outcomes. The research advances science by developing new methods that can be used to analyze situations from whether to regulate a durable goods monopolist to how labor markets can do a better job of helping employers find the right employees.

The first project explores dynamic pricing strategies of monopolists in environments with general market demands and production technologies. The goal is to characterize the relationship between monopoly power and production technology, and study how the consumer and producer surpluses in dynamic models differ from the static model. This work will provide a new and more general foundation for the fast growing literature in empirical economics on dynamic pricing of durable goods. The second project seeks to advance the study of the core and stability in matching markets with incomplete information. The research agenda includes offering practically relevant refinements of existing concepts, finding dynamic game foundations of the concept of pairwise stability, characterizing the precise relationship between the core and stability, and analyzing stable matchings in various environments such as those with costly investment and hidden types.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF funding SES-1824328 has produced 3 publications in the top five journals in economics, two complete and circulated working papers, and one paper that is work in progress.  

(1)  “Auctions with limited commitment” (joint with Konrad Mierendorff, Xianwen Shi, Weijie Zhong) American Economic Review, March 2019. This paper revisits Myerson’s (1981) celebrated optimal auction design, allowing the auctioneer to offer new auctions with lower reserve prices when the initial auction ends without a sale. The paper shows that the received insights must be revised. With at least three buyers, an immediate sale with efficient allocations is optimal. For many distributions of buyer valuations, two buyers are sufficient for this result to hold. This research is important because it sheds light on optimal auction designs, which have significant real-world implications in various industries such as dynamic airline pricing, online advertising, and procurement, improving our understanding of the tradeoff between economic efficiency and revenue generation.

(2)  “Stability and Bayesian Consistency in Two-Sided Markets” American Economic Review, August 2020. This paper defines a Bayesian notion of pairwise stability for two-sided markets with one-sided incomplete information. This framework is important because incomplete information is prevalent in various real-world matching situations, such as labor markets (matching job seekers with employers), healthcare (matching patients with providers), marriage and dating markets (matching women with men), online advertising (matching ads with users), and financial markets (matching buyers and sellers of financial instruments). However, the celebrated theory of Gale and Shapley (1962) and Shapley and Shubik (1971) are confined to complete-information problems.

(3)  “Strategic Exploration: Preemption and Prioritization” (joint with Yu Fu Wong) Review of Economic Studies, August 2023. This paper delves into competitive strategic exploration, exploring the balance between preemption and prioritization. It offers insights into how this balance influences behaviors and outcomes in contexts like technology races and R&D competitions. The model reveals the rationale for different parties to engage in destructive competition, but also explores conditions under which coordination can be achieved. This paper offers some insights into superpower competitions.

(4)  “Cooperative Analysis of Incomplete Information,” revision requested by Econometrica. This paper offers a coherent theory of stability in cooperative games with incomplete information. In the realm of strategic interactions with incomplete information, non-cooperative games have often been the primary focus, but there has been limited progress in adopting a cooperative approach. Cooperative games are reduced-form models of complicated strategic interactions; their applications are well known under complete information, e.g., in market design and network formation. But these important areas have been significantly underdeveloped when there is incomplete information. This paper offers a general theory of cooperative games of incomplete information and explores its implications in matching with two-sided incomplete information and network formation problems with incomplete information.

(5)  “Matching with Incomplete Information” is solicited for Handbook of Economics of Matching, edited by Yeon-Koo Che, Pierre-André Chiappori, and Bernard Salanie. This paper reviews the nascent field of matching with incomplete information and its connections to other areas of research. More importantly, the paper discuss open questions for young researchers.

(6)  “A General Theory of Durable Good Monopoly”. This project, which is still a work in progress, explores a monopolist’s price strategy under general demand functions and supply functions. The main result characterizes the conditions under which the monopolist can achieve a profit higher than the efficient benchmark. This result will improve our understanding of efficiency and monopoly power.

 

The NSF funding also trains graduate students. Yu Fu Wong, a graduate student supported by the grant as a research assistant, received his Ph.D. from Columbia in 2023. He is currently an assistant professor of economics at the University of Warwick, one of the top schools in economic theory in the UK. He is the coauthor of the paper ““Strategic Exploration: Preemption and Prioritization.” Ziyang Shen, currently a fourth-year graduate student at Columbia, also worked as a research assistant funded by this grant, has developed a research project on Shapley-Scarf exchange economy of incomplete information, extending the ideas described in this funded project. Paul Sungwook Koh, who received his Ph.D. from Columbia in 2022, wrote a thesis on econometric theory, which is also inspired by the ideas developed in this project. Paul is currently an economist at the Federal Trade Commission.
